children.subject: Okay, it turns out that there isn't a provision for getting waitlisted in advance.  Just wait until the semester starts, and show up to the first lecture.

Hello Prof. Shewchuk, I tried enrolling in the class but got the following message "Permission to enroll in this class is required. The class falls outside your career of study. Choose another class." It seems that the CalCentral system is barring me from even getting onto the waiting list as an undergraduate student.

I'll do two lectures on robot motion planning.  Basic but important stuff on configuration spaces and Minkowsky sums.

Before that, I'll also teach several algorithms that lead up to that:  for example, line intersection algorithms and planar subdivision overlay algorithms are an important part of Minkowski sum algorithms.
Hi professor, I am thinking about taking the class. Can you give some advice on how helpful is computational geometry to robot motion planning?

The one thing you need for CS 274 is the ability to do mathematical proofs.

 

CS 170 (or an equivalent undergrad algs class) is helpful too (we use some graph algorithms, and I'll be asking you to design new algorithms), but you can probably get by without it.
I looked at one of the previous course websites but could you please throw some light on the prerequisites for this class, specifically for an undergrad?

history.content:
UPDATE:  I previously said undergrads could waitlist, but that's incorrect; just wait until the first day of class.

If you're an undergraduate student who would like to take my class Computational Geometry (CS 274) this spring, show up on the first day of class and speak to me right after class.  I'll admit undergraduates if there's room (once the grad students have had a chance).

The size of CS 274 is limited by the fact that I'll have no TA and grade all the homeworks myself.  This has never been a problem in the past--I've always been able to accommodate every undergrad who wanted to take the class--but I can't guarantee that this will be true again until the semester starts.  (Grad students tend to enroll at the last minute.)

(This note is for undergraduates.  If you're a graduate student wanting to take CS 274, just enroll as usual.)

Thanks,

Jonathan Shewchuk
history.subject: Info on enrolling in CS 274 for undergraduates (corrected)

history.content:
If you're an undergraduate student who would like to take my class Computational Geometry (CS 274) this spring, get on the waitlist, show up on the first day of class, and speak to me right after class.  I'll admit undergraduates if there's room (once the grad students have had a chance).

The size of CS 274 is limited by the fact that I'll have no TA and grade all the homeworks myself.  This has never been a problem in the past--I've always been able to accommodate every undergrad who wanted to take the class--but I can't guarantee that this will be true again until the semester starts.

(This note is for undergraduates.  If you're a graduate student wanting to take CS 274, just enroll as usual.)

Thanks,

Jonathan Shewchuk
